editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. The approximately 40,000 texts produced during Phase 2 (2009- ), of which 34,963 had been released as of 2020, originally similarly restricted, were similarly freed from all restrictions on 1 August 2020. As of that date anyone is free to take and use these texts for any purpose (modify them, annotate them, distribute them, etc.). But we do respectfully request that due credit and attribution be given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.head: A Declaration of His HIGHNESS, for a Collection towards the relief of divers Prote≈øtant Churches driven out of Poland; And of Twenty Prote≈øtant Families driven out of the Confines of Bohemia.
div.p:
HIs Highne≈øs the Lord Protector, having received a Petition from ≈øeveral Churches of Chri≈øt, profe≈ø≈øing the Reformed Religion, lately ≈øeated at Le≈øna, and other places in Poland, repre≈øenting their ≈øad and deplorable condition, through the per≈øecution and cruelty of their Antichri≈øtian Enemies in tho≈øe parts, in the time of the War in Poland, by whom they have not onely been driven from their habitation, and ≈øpoiled of their goods upon the account of Religion onely, but forced to flie into Sile≈øia for pre≈øervation of their lives, and for the Liberty of their Con≈øciences, where a con≈øiderable
number of them continue in great want and mi≈øery. The truth whereof hath been witne≈ø≈øed, a≈øwel by Deputies ≈øent unto His Highne≈øs from the ≈øaid Churches, authorized by an In≈øtrument under the hands of the Pa≈øtors of five of tho≈øe Churches, as al≈øo by the Te≈øtimony of ≈øeveral Prote≈øtant Princes, who out of a deep ≈øence of the Calamity of tho≈øe di≈øtre≈ø≈øed Exiles, have afforded them ≈øhelter until it ≈øhall plea≈øe the Lord otherwi≈øe to provide for them. And His Highne≈øs having in like manner received a Petition from Twenty Prote≈øtant Families heretofore ≈øeated in the Confines of Bohemia, where Mi≈ønia belongs unto it, repre≈øenting their di≈øtre≈ø≈øed and lamentable condition, through the per≈øecution of the Ie≈øuites and Inqui≈øitors of the Hou≈øe of Au≈øtria, by whom they have been driven out of their habitations, and ≈øpoiled of their goods, upon the ≈øole accompt of Religion, who now for the ≈øafety of their lives, and for the liberties of their Con≈øciences, are retired into the Marqui≈øate of Culembach, where they finde a pre≈øent ≈øhelter in this their very ≈øad and calamitous condition, which hath been witne≈ø≈øed both by their Deputies ≈øent unto His Highne≈øs, authorized by an In≈øtrument under the hands of the chief of tho≈øe Families, as al≈øo by a publique Certificate from thence. And it being the earne≈øt de≈øire of the ≈øaid afflicted Churches and Families, a≈øwel by their ≈øeveral Petitions, as by their Deputies, that His Highne≈øs out of compa≈ø≈øion to their ≈øufferings, would be plea≈øed to recommend their lamentable condition to their Brethren in the≈øe Nations, in whom they hope to finde Bowels of Mercy, yearning
towards tho≈øe, who profe≈ø≈øing the ≈øame Faith with them, are now under ≈øo great extremities and mi≈øery for the Cau≈øe of the Go≈øpel, and te≈øtimony of the Lord Je≈øus.

His Highne≈øs being greatly afflicted with the mi≈øerable and calamitous condition of the ≈øaid Churches, and Families, and not doubting but the people of the≈øe Nations, whom the Lord hath graciou≈øly and wonderfully pre≈øerved from that Antichri≈øtian Bondage and Tyranny, will have a fellow-feeling of the afflictions of their Brethren, hath with the Advice of His Privy-Council, thought fit to recommend their ca≈øe to the Charity of tho≈øe who≈øe hearts the Lord ≈øhall ≈øtir up in the≈øe Nations, to afford them ≈øome ≈øea≈øonable relief, who≈øe liberality in this kind hath been te≈øtified in their large Contributions to the relief of the poor Prote≈øtants in the Valleys of Piedmont, to the refre≈øhing of their Bowels (touching the faithful di≈øtribution whereof an account is ordered by His Highne≈øs to be printed for general ≈øatisfaction.) And to the end the ≈øaid Collections may be carefully made, and the moneys thereupon collected be di≈øpo≈øed of, to the relief of the ≈øaid poor Churches, and their Members, and the Families afore≈øaid, and to no other u≈øes, His Highne≈øs doth hereby require and command the Mini≈øters and Churchwardens of the re≈øpective Pari≈øhes within England and Wales and Town of Berwick upon Tweed, the next Lords Day after this Declaration ≈øhall come unto their hands, to publi≈øh the ≈øame, and on the Lords day following to make a Collection of the charitable Contribution of the People in their Pari≈øhes, and that within
three dayes after, they pay over the ≈øum or ≈øums ≈øo Collected unto the high Sherif of the re≈øpective Counties, to be by him paid into the hands of Sir Thomas Viner, and Sir Chri≈øtopher Pack Knights, Aldermen of the City of London, who are appointed Trea≈øurers for this ≈øervice, and who ≈øhall tran≈ømit the moneys ≈øo to be by them received for the relief of the ≈øaid poor di≈øtre≈ø≈øed Churches, and their Members, and the afore≈øaid Twenty families, in ≈øuch manner and proportions as the Committee formerly appointed for the di≈øpo≈øing of the moneys for the relief of the ≈øaid poor Prote≈øtants in Piedmont, ≈øhall, with re≈øpect to their ≈øeveral numbers and ≈øufferings, think fit, and direct, and to the end none of the moneys collected for ≈øo pious and charitable an end may mi≈øcarry, The Mini≈øter and Churchwardens afore≈øaid, are enjoyned upon payment of the ≈øaid money to the re≈øpective Sheriffs as afore≈øaid, to ≈øend up unto the ≈øaid Sir Thomas Viner a note in writing under their hands, of the ≈øum ≈øo Collected, the Pari≈øh and County where ≈øuch Collection was made, and the per≈øon to whom the ≈øame was paid, to the end care may be taken, and the ≈øame may be duly returned and imployed to the u≈øe intended.
